Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Offspring Methylation Patterns in Relation to Maternal Stress in a Non-Western Population

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of my research is to understand how early life environmental influences can shape human biology and later life health. During my NSF EAPSI fellowship I worked at the Liggins Institute in Auckland, New Zealand, which is one of the premier perinatal research Institutes in the world. I learned laboratory methods and made contacts that will allow me to conduct my dissertation research in Auckland. I learned how to extract DNA from cheek swab and umbilical cord samples, amplify that DNA and look for modifications on that DNA (methylation) that affect the way that genes are turned on and off. One of the experiments that we conducted compared whether DNA modifications differ depending on what cell type within the umbilical cord we evaluate. We found that there were differences between cell types. When not in the laboratory I volunteered at local high schools and gave lectures on human evolution, and also gave several seminars to anthropology, molecular biology and population health research groups.

    For my dissertation research I will return to Auckland to recruit pregnant women for my study. I will evaluate maternal stress physiology via the stress hormone cortisol, and ask about percieved stress experience with survey questionnaires. I will then look at stress physiology of infants as well as changes in DNA markings (methylation) using the laboratory methods I learned in my EAPSI fellowship. This research has important impacts for our understanding of how the social environment becomes physically embodied by modifying patterns of gene expression through DNA modifications.


Last Modified: 06/30/2011
Modified by: Zaneta M Thayer
